1. INTERESTING QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in eastern Canada? .......... 1934
Where did you set up housekeeping? .......... Newmarket, Ontario
How far had you been living before that? .......... Toronto, Ontario
For how many people did you prepare meals? .......... 2
How far was it to your nearest store? .......... About 20 miles
How often could you visit the store? .......... About once in 2 weeks
What groceries did you usually buy in those early years?
Flour, Oatsmeal, Sugar, Rice, Syrup occasionally.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand or white flour did you use in the early years? .......... National
In what quantities did you buy it? .......... 100 lbs
Was there any price per hundred pounds of white flour? .......... Yes
How much did you use per month? .......... 5 lbs
Was flour milled locally? .......... No
Was flour milled locally? .......... Yes
Was the price for a twenty pound bar of rolled oats? .......... Yes
What other grain products did you use? .......... Cornmeal
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? .......... No
How did you grind it? .......... By hand

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) ..........................................................

How far was this water from your home? ...........................................

How was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel, tank) ........................

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Later a well was dug near the house door and afterwards the water was piped through the cellar and there was a pump in the kitchen.

16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

At first food was bought mostly in bulk and wrapped in paper until later when paper bags were procurable. Now foods are packaged for the most part.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

BREAKFAST: Oatmeal porridge, Bread & Butter, Dried Apple Pie, Tea.

DINNER: Boiled Potatoes, Fried Pork, Bread & Butter, Tea.

SUPPER: Fried Potatoes, Left-over Pork, Bread & Butter, Cake, Tea.

Year 1894. Two in family - my husband and I.

Menu was much the same the year round.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada?

..................... Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No, we always had plenty to eat as we had home products.
25. **SHOPPING AND DINNERIES**

   Mention any changes which you recall in the shopping and cooking habits.

   At first food was bought mostly in bulk and wrapped in paper until later when paper bags were procurable. New foods are purchased for the most part.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate monthly cost, etc., winter or summer.

   **BREAKFAST:** Oatmeal porridge, bread & butter, dried apple pie, tea.

   **DINNER:** Roasted potatoes, fried pork, bread & butter, tea.

   **SUPPER:** Fried potatoes, left-over pork, bread & butter, cake, tea.

   Year 1930. Two in family - my husband and I.

   Meals were much the same the year round.

18. That year did you serve your Christmas dinner in natural foods?

   Yes, we always had plenty to eat as we had home products.

19. Have you ever refused to attempt starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

   No, we always had plenty to eat as we had home products.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Today there is more variety and more vegetables and fruits are used.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home-prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

We still use mostly homegrown and home-prepared foods.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Eastern Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

When we first came we brought small quantities with us of various food stuffs.

For a number of years a box of foodstuffs was sent us from the East - crock of preserved fruit, dried apples, raisins, currants, etc. - not large quantities but quite a treat.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Today there is more variety and more vegetables and fruits are used.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home-prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Eastern Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

When we first came we brought small quantities with us of various food stuffs.

For a number of years a box of foodstuffs was sent us from the East - cask of preserved fruit, dried apples, raisins, currants, etc. - not large quantities but quite a treat.
